reporting-org.narrative: Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland

title.narrative: F.a: Project for Improving Women’s Livelihood (PIWL)

description.narrative: The project will have the overall objective to alleviate poverty in Myanmar through maximising the role of women in rural development. This will be achieved through the facilitation of the formation of Women Groups (WGs) that are able to mobilise resources to support village development works, and by increasing their capacity to have increased participation in village level decision making processes. The WGs will also be supported in networking with government, village and township authorities, by taking tr aining in leadership, networking, and proposal writing skills. Secondly the project will focus on empowering women to obtain improved and sustainable socio-economic livelihoods.Based on the assessment done in the project area’s women groups following the pilot phase, it was evident that women members understand the importance of the group and how the savings and credit scheme can support to improve their livelihoods. The groups want more intensive facilitation and support in the areas of management, book keeping, entrepreneurship skills, linking with other actors - basically to connect to markets and legalising the women’s groups. Expected results are:• Women’s Groups are able to mobilise resources to support village development works and have increa sed participation in village level decision-making process.• Women increase skills and knowledge in village development decisions-making and activities.• Improved and sustainable socio-economic livelihoods. This is done through activities as support in the areas of management, bookkeeping, entrepreneurship skills, linking with other actors - basically to connect to markets and legalising the women’s groups.Rights-holders /beneficiaries: Direct beneficiaries are poor and marginalised women - 22 Women g roups, 407 members. Indirect beneficiaries are total 10,800 people.Implementing partner:Lutheran World Federation (LWF) Myanmar. LWF Myanmar works effectively with local authorities and civil society organisations and has been active in the area since 2008 . It works at the grassroots with partner households and interest groups and the VDCs (Village Development Committees). Increasingly in a changing institutional environment LWF stresses more cooperation and involvement with local leaders/authorities and tr aditional leaders. They play a crucial role in enhancing or blocking innovation and change. Thus, networking and advocacy are part of the Rights Based Empowerment approach LWF applies in Myanmar.
